CISO  I looked through your Python script for selecting secret word comments to see how it worked, and I noticed that you made a function to delete old CSV files used for previous contests. Your program then creates a new CSV file to replace the old file and appends new data to that file.   However, this process could be simplified by opening the file (using Python's built-in open function) and overwriting it to turn it into a blank CSV. From there, your new data can be appended to the same file. That way you do not have to delete a file and then make a new one.

NIST CISO 800-53 RMF I found this video incredibly insightful and thought-provoking. The discussion on the value of certifications, particularly CompTIA Security Plus, was enlightening. The comparison between Security Plus and Google's cyber security program was also intriguing, highlighting each option's strengths and considerations. Thank you for sharing this valuable information!

Secret word: CISO  Comment #4  My other request would be to get some guidance on where to focus when you are new into the field of cybersecurity. I have currently put a hold on stacking up the certs and focusing more on polishing my skills through platforms like hackthebox and tryhackme etc. However, since the platform is pretty broad and covers various aspects and topics, is it a good choice to stick with these platforms or should we be picking a skill (for example linux) and just focus on that for a few weeks before moving on to something else. I feel like there is SO MUCH to practice out there that it easily overwhelms a layman like myself and I feel like I am racing against time.

CISO I think the way you talk about preparing yourself in every area as much as possible is just what I need. I tend to have more anxiety with the social aspects (interviewing, discussing technical terms, networking) but it has to  be done. Using chatgpt has helped a ton so far and I've been practicing at home just talking to myself about the topics I struggle with the most. Hopefully by interview time, I'll be able to discuss security topics with no problem.

CISO  I totally agree that Certs =/= Technical Ability. I have, and currently work with government contracts that require techs have Sec+, and half the people I've worked with cannot even competently troubleshoot basic end user problems. It's more of a contractual requirement for the employer, and a gatekeeper for resumes to get through HR.   I'm revisiting A+ due to WGU's coursework, and find that a lot of principles I've shared from A+ (most notably their troubleshooting methodology) was WAY more beneficial for techs, than the entire Sec+ certification. This opinion is of course focused around those help desk roles, but regardless...a certification is only a small  piece of the puzzle. And HOW you gained that cert is equally important. Memorizing answers =/= learning the content and applying it until you understand it.   Thanks once again for the great content!
